head.title: Emmys Go to 'Practice' and 'Frasier' as Top Series

identified-content.object.title: Practice, the (TV Program)
Frasier (TV Program)
identified-content.classifier: Top/Classifieds/Job Market/Job Categories/Media, Entertainment and Publishing

hedline.hl1: Emmys Go to 'Practice' and 'Frasier' as Top Series

abstract.p: Emmy Awards ceremonies held; winners include The Practice (Drama Series), Frasier (Comedy Series), Andre Braugher (Leading Actor in Drama Series) and Christine Lahti (Leading Actress in Drama Series); other winners listed; photo (M)

block.p: In an evening that emphasized the nostalgia of the past rather than the immense uncertainty of the future of television, there were a number of surprise winners in the Emmy Awards here tonight and further signs that cable channels are making increasing creative inroads against the traditional broadcast networks.

A new show, ''The Practice,'' the tale of a tough, young law firm, won as best drama series, a marked instance of new blood in this category. In the comedy-series category, ''Frasier,'' about an earnest radio therapist, Dr. Frasier Crane, set a record in taking the Emmy. It was the fifth consecutive Emmy for the show, the first time any show has won so many of the statuettes, breaking a record that had seemed as unassailable as Roger Maris's single-season home-run mark. Four shows had tied for the record, including ''Cheers,'' from which ''Frasier'' had been spun off.''Frasier,'' which runs on NBC, has won every year it has been on the air.

In an evening that emphasized the nostalgia of the past rather than the immense uncertainty of the future of television, there were a number of surprise winners in the Emmy Awards here tonight and further signs that cable channels are making increasing creative inroads against the traditional broadcast networks.

A new show, ''The Practice,'' the tale of a tough, young law firm, won as best drama series, a marked instance of new blood in this category. In the comedy-series category, ''Frasier,'' about an earnest radio therapist, Dr. Frasier Crane, set a record in taking the Emmy. It was the fifth consecutive Emmy for the show, the first time any show has won so many of the statuettes, breaking a record that had seemed as unassailable as Roger Maris's single-season home-run mark. Four shows had tied for the record, including ''Cheers,'' from which ''Frasier'' had been spun off.''Frasier,'' which runs on NBC, has won every year it has been on the air.

In addition, Kelsey Grammer, who plays Frasier, and David Hyde Pierce, who plays his stuffy, emotionally repressed brother, Miles, took the Emmys as best lead actor in a comedy series and best supporting actor in a comedy series, respectively. Helen Hunt won her third Emmy as best lead actress in a comedy, for ''Mad About You,'' and best supporting actress went to Lisa Kudrow, the not always coherent Phoebe in ''Friends.''

The best lead actor in a drama award went to Andre Braugher, who won his first Emmy in his last season as a tough detective in ''Homicide: Life on the Street.'' The Emmy for best lead actress in a drama went to Christine Lahti, a surgeon in ''Chicago Hope.'' This was the 50th anniversary of the telecast of the Emmys, which are presented by the Academy of Television Arts and Sciences. The ceremony was held at the Shrine Auditorium near downtown Los Angeles.

The program this year was heavier on nostalgia than usual, with a series of clips and moments commemorating people like the Marx Brothers and Ed Sullivan, and shows like ''Gunsmoke,'' ''Father Knows Best'' and ''American Bandstand.'' There was a long standing ovation when Bob Hope, Milton Berle and Sid Caesar appeared together onstage. The presenters also showed the moment when it was revealed who shot J. R. on ''Dallas'' 18 years ago.

The academy and television executives were eager to focus on creative achievements rather than the uncertainty of the future of a medium being fragmented by many new channels and squabbles that have taken place behind the scenes for several years.

They were pleased that a number of new shows won nominations and that first-time actors took some of the Emmys. Several people also noted that, in addition to ''Frasier's'' setting a record, the writer and producer David E. Kelley also came close to setting one. He was the first producer ever to have two shows, one drama, ''The Practice,'' and one comedy, ''Ally McBeal,'' nominated for best series in their categories. Though just one of the shows won the award, it was regarded as a striking creative achievement and a sign of the vibrancy of the medium.
But there were reminders of simmering resentments within the industry.
One of the more striking victories was in the mini-series category, long dominated by the broadcast networks. This year four of the five Emmy nominees were from cable channels.
The winner, the 12-part, hugely expensive ''From the Earth to the Moon,'' was produced by HBO and had stirred up a bitter debate even before the ceremony.

Some network executives had complained that the program, of which Tom Hanks was executive producer, did not technically qualify as a mini-series, but those charges were rejected by the academy. The only network nominee this year was NBC's ''Merlin.''

HBO also continued its streak in the original movie category. The channel won in this category for the sixth consecutive year for ''Don King: Only in America.'' That movie also won for best writing, with a script by Kario Salem.

Last year, some network executives had pushed to have the cable channels placed in a separate original-movie category because of allegations that they could spend more money than the broadcast networks on their films. The academy also rejected that campaign.
NBC received some consolation in the fact that it took more Emmys, 18, than any other company. ABC trailed with 16 and HBO came in third with 14.

Camryn Manheim, the earnest lawyer, Ellenor Frutt, in ''The Practice,'' took the Emmy for best supporting actress in a drama series. In one of the more memorable acceptance speeches of the evening, the heavyset Ms. Manheim thanked her friends and supporters, asked if she could get the autographs of her fellow nominees, then shouted, ''This is for all the fat girls!''
The Emmy for best supporting actor in a drama went to Gordon Clapp, Detective Greg Medavoy in ''N.Y.P.D. Blue.'' It was Ms. Manheim's first time nominated and Mr. Clapp's second.

Peter Tolan and Garry Shandling took the honor as best writers in a comedy series for ''The Larry Sanders Show.'' It was the first Emmy Mr. Shandling had won after having garnered 19 nominations over the years.
Similarly, ''Late Show With David Letterman'' won the Emmy for best variety, music or comedy series, the first time it has taken an Emmy after 19 fruitless nominations in various categories.

The Emmy for best actor in a movie or mini-series went to Gary Sinise for ''George Wallace.'' He had been nominated previously for his role as Harry Truman in ''Truman.'' The Emmy for best actress in a movie or mini-series went to Ellen Barkin for her role in ''Before Women Had Wings.''
''From the Earth to the Moon,'' HBO
Ellen Barkin, ''Before Women Had Wings,'' ABC
George C. Scott, ''12 Angry Men,'' Showtime
Performance in a variety or music program:
Billy Crystal, ''The 70th Annual Academy Awards,'' ABC
Mark Tinker, ''Brooklyn South: Pilot,'' CBS, and Paris Barclay, ''N.Y.P.D. Blue: Lost Israel, Part II,'' ABC (tie)
Todd Holland, ''The Larry Sanders Show: Flip,'' HBO
Louis J. Horvitz, ''The 70th Annual Academy Awards,'' ABC
Nicholas Wootton and David Milch, ''N.Y.P.D. Blue: Lost Israel, Part II,'' ABC
Peter Tolan and Garry Shandling, ''The Larry Sanders Show: Flip,'' HBO
Eddie Feldmann, Dennis Miller, David Feldman, Leah Krinsky, Jim Hanna, David Weiss and Jose Arroyo, ''Dennis Miller Live,'' HBO
Writing for a mini-series or movie:
Kario Salem, ''Don King: Only in America,'' HBO

Correction: September 17, 1998, Thursday A list of this year's Emmy Awards on Tuesday and in some copies on Monday omitted one of those honored for writing for a drama series. Along with Nicholas Wootton and David Milch, Bill Clark received the Emmy for work on an episode of ''N.Y.P.D. Blue.''

A list of this year's Emmy Awards on Tuesday and in some copies on Monday omitted one of those honored for writing for a drama series. Along with Nicholas Wootton and David Milch, Bill Clark received the Emmy for work on an episode of ''N.Y.P.D. Blue.''
